Algunas armas de fuego indican un número entre paréntesis después de la propiedad de fallo de disparo. Si el d20 de su tirada de ataque es igual o inferior al número indicado, antes de cualquier modificador, el cañón del arma está sucio. Cuando no se saca un 1 natural, es posible que dicho ataque alcance su objetivo y aún así resulte en un cañón ensuciado.

Si tienes una característica de clase que aumenta el índice de fallo de disparo de un arma, y el arma carece de esta propiedad, añade la propiedad de fallo de disparo con un índice igual a lo que hubiera sido el aumento.

items.name: Tripping
entries: {@i This weapon is well suited to hook or wrap around your target's supporting limbs, causing it to fall.}

Mientras empuñas esta arma, obtienes un bonificador +2 a tus chequeos de Fuerza ({@skill Athletics}) para {@action shove|PHB|shoving} una criatura si intentas golpearla {@condition prone}. Aumenta este bonificador a +3 si el arma es de dos manos (o es versátil y se usa a dos manos), o si estás blandiendo dos armas de una mano que tengan cada una esta propiedad.
Estos beneficios no se aplican a una Maniobra de Combate {@optfeature Trip Attack}, que utiliza técnicas no relacionadas para tropezar e infligir daño con el mismo golpe.

items.name: Unarmed (B), (P), or (S)
entries: Un dispositivo con esta propiedad se coloca en los nudillos, los dedos o el dorso de la mano. A menudo adopta la forma de un guante. A veces se trata de un conjunto de anillos en los dedos (conectados o no) que son bastante pesados o llevan salientes afilados.

Este dispositivo puede modificar los ataques sin armas del portador. Si esta propiedad de arma está anotada (P) o (S), los ataques sin armas que utilicen el dispositivo pueden infligir daño punzante o cortante en lugar de daño contundente. Este dispositivo no restringe los ataques sin armas del usuario, que pueden realizarse con otras partes del cuerpo.

Los dispositivos con la propiedad de desarmado no se agarran a la mano, por lo que no impiden al portador sujetar otra cosa o utilizar de otro modo la mano afectada. Un dispositivo con esta propiedad requiere una acción para ponerse o quitarse, una tarea que requiere ambas manos. No se puede desarmar.

Los dispositivos desarmados pueden hacerse mágicos como las armas. También pueden ser plateados o construidos con materiales exóticos, lo que aumenta la eficacia y versatilidad de tus golpes desarmados.

items.name: Wounding
entries: {@i The sharp portions of a wounding weapon leave viciously-shaped injuries that are prone to bleeding.}

Si un objetivo recibe daño de uno o más ataques de herida, sufre 1 punto de daño por pérdida de sangre al final de su siguiente turno. Cualquier curación que se produzca entre la herida y el final del turno de la criatura evita el daño. Ligar la herida también evita el daño, lo que requiere una acción y un chequeo de Sabiduría ({@skill Medicine}) con éxito contra una DC de 10 o gastar un uso de un {@item healer's kit}.
Las criaturas sin sistema circulatorio son inmunes a esta propiedad.

disease.name: Aboleth Slime
entries: A creature that comes into contact with this slime must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or become diseased. The disease has no effect for 1 minute and can be removed by any magic that cures disease. After 1 minute, the diseased creature's skin becomes translucent and slimy, the creature can't regain hit points unless it is underwater, and the disease can be removed only by heal or another di sease-curing spell of 6th level or higher. When the creature is outside a body of water, it takes 6 {@damage 1d12} acid damage every 10 minutes unless moisture is applied to the skin before 10 minutes have passed.

disease.name: Beastial Rage
entries: The magical disease spreads through close contact with infected creatures, and affects humanoids and most animals. Bestial rage is sometimes known as "crimson fury", especially in regions where barbarians are common. The disease spreads via the bodily fluids of infected creatures, typically blood or saliva. Simply handling infected fluid is seldom enough to transmit the disease and it must enter the body, such as through an injury. Being bitten by an infected creature is a common means of transmission, as is killing an infected creature with a melee weapon while injured.

When exposed to the disease, a humanoid creature or beast must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or become infected. If within 10 minutes of exposure the affected areas are thoroughly washed or treated with a DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check the creature has advantage on the saving throw to avoid infection. Onset of the disease varies wildly depending on the strain and virility, with early symptoms appearing after 2d6 days, 1d6 weeks, or 1d4 months. Particularly aggressive strains might manifest after as little as 3d6 hours.

Symptoms of bestial rage include a fever, disorientation, and a sore throat. An infected creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw to eat or drink. Infected creatures are irritable and aggressive, attacking wildly when startled or injured. When attacked or otherwise provoked, the infected creature must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or fly into a mindless rage, similar to that of a barbarian, making melee attacks with advantage while attacks against the infected creature also have advantage. The raging creature tried to make melee attacks against a creature each round, favouring enemies over allies. Each round they do not attack a creature, the infected creature can repeat the saving throw.

When an infected creature suffers a level of exhaustion, typically from dehydration, their irritability increases and the DC to avoid this rage increases to 15. Bestial rage resists most natural curatives and mundane remedies, and remains until cured by spells such as {@spell lesser restoration|PHB} or {@spell heal|PHB}.

disease.name: Black Vomit
entries: Spread through biting insects, this disease can infect humanoid creatures and most types of livestock. Black vomit is most common in regions bordering wetlands, such as swamps and marshes. After spending 12-hours in an area with insects carrying the disease, a humanoid creature must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or become infected. Alchemical repellents, spells, and other effects that ward against insects can confer either advantage on the saving throw or outright immunity depending on the nature and potency of the effect.

The disease incubates for {@dice 1d4} days, after which symptoms appear, including fever, chills, nausea, and pains throughout the back and head. Infected creatures find it difficult to keep down food and their vomit is black. An infected creature must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw to drink water (or similar fluids such as milk or potions) and a DC 15 Constitution saving throw to eat food, vomiting everything consumed in the last few hours on a failure. Creatures unable to consume enough food and drink are subject to the starvation rules.

At the end of each long rest, the affected creature must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a success the DC for this saving throw is reduced by 1d4. When the DC of the saving throw drops to 0 the creature has recovered from the disease. If a creature naturally recovers from black vomit, they are immune to this disease and cannot be infected again.

disease.name: Bloody Flux
entries: This stomach ailment is contracted by consuming contaminated water or food, or contact with unsanitary conditions. If often affects travellers in distant lands, who are unaccustomed to the water or food. When a creature comes in contact with the disease they must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or become infected. If the creature has consumed contaminated food or drink, they have disadvantage on this saving throw. Symptoms of the disease begin after {@dice 1d3} days. Infected creatures develop a mild fever, stomach pain, and have a frequent need to defecate, but their stool is liquidy and black or bloody. An infected creature suffers 1 level of exhaustion.

While the creature has at least 1 level of exhaustion they must consume twice the normal amount of water each day. After each long rest, the infected creature must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw. If they did not drink enough water the previous day, the creature has disadvantage on this saving throw. On a failure they gain 1 level of exhaustion. On a success the creature's level of exhaustion is reduced by 1 level. When a successful saving throw reduces the creature's level of exhaustion below 1 the creature has recovered from the disease.

disease.name: Combustion Fever
entries: When this disease reaches its final stage its victims burst into flames, and their ashes spreading the sickness to new victims when they touch or inhale the ashes Humanoid creatures that come into contact with the disease must make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or become infected. Creatures that do not breath have advantage on this saving throw as they do not risk inhaling the contaminated ashes.

The first symptoms of the disease appear in {@dice 1d4 + 1} hours, as the victim develops an intense fever and sore skin. The infected creature suffers 1 level of exhaustion, and is vulnerable to cold damage while they have at least 1 level of exhaustion. At the end of each long rest, the infected creature takes 3 {@damage 1d6} fire damage for each level of exhaustion they possess. If the creature reaches level 6 of exhaustion they burst into flames that consume their entire body leaving only a fine dust. All creatures within 10 feet of infected creature when it combusts must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw or take 27 {@damage 5d10} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Creatures that take this fire damage are likely also exposed to the disease. At the end of each long rest, an infected creature must make a DC 16 Constitution saving throw. On a failure they gains one level of exhaustion. On a successful saving throw, the character's exhaustion level decreases by 1 level. If a successful saving throw reduces the infected creature's level of exhaustion below 1, the creature recovers from the disease.

disease.name: Crimson Death
entries: Entire towns have been killed by this virulent and deadly plague. Thankfully, the disease is now rare due to efforts at controlling outbreaks, such as burning the bodies of the dead. Blood contaminated with this disease remains contagious for years, and there have been reports of delvers becoming infected while exploring crypts where victims of the crimson death were interred. This disease is primarily spread through contact with infected blood, although any bodily fluid can transfer the disease.

A humanoid creature that touches contaminated fluids must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw or catch the disease. Symptoms of the disease begin after 1d4 days, causing the creature to cough blood and develop weeping sores across their body. Infected creatures suffer 1 level of exhaustion. At the end of end of each long rest an infected creature takes 11 (2d6) necrotic damage and must make a DC 16 Constitution saving throw. On a failure the creature gains 1 level of exhaustion. On a successful save the DC of the saving throw is reduced by 1d6. When the saving throw DC becomes 0, the creature recovers from the disease.

disease.name: Crystalline Sickness
entries: This disease slowly turns the victim's bodily fluids into crystal. Sufferers die painfully as their blood hardens in their veins, crystals burst through their skin, and their lungs become incapable of taking in air. After death, the crystalline body crumbles into a fine red sand. This powder contains the disease in a dormant state, and only becomes active when exposed to water. Creatures exposed to the disease must make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or become infected.

Symptoms of the disease progress steadily at a fixed rate. The day after infection the infected creature experiences joint pain and a low fever. Exactly 3 days following infection patches of the infected creature's skin begin to harden. 8 days after the infection, the creatures eyes solidify and their joints harden. The infected creature has disadvantage on all Dexterity checks and their base movement speed is halved, but they have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) and Intelligence (Investigation) checks relying on sight. After 18 days the infected creature must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw every hour or begin to suffocate. There is no cure for the crystal virus. Creatures suffering from the disease remain infected until the disease is cured by spells such as {@spell lesser restoration|phb} or {@spell heal|phb}.

disease.name: Delver's Malady
entries: This affliction is common among those who spend lengthy periods of time surviving on preserved rations or magically created food, such as adventurers, sailors, and soldiers. Races accustomed to living underground are often naturally immune to this disease, including mountain dwarves, gnomes, drow elves, and half-orcs. After a month without fresh food, especially fruits and vegetables, a humanoid creature must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature has developed delver's malady and begins to show symptoms. On a success, the creature has avoided the disease but must repeat the saving throw in another month unless they consume fresh food. Infected creatures become lethargic, with a spongy tongue and gums, and slight bleeding from the nose and ears. The infected creature suffers 1 level of exhaustion.

While the creature has 1 level of exhaustion the number of Hit Dice they regain after a long rest is halved. Until fresh food is consumed, the disease cannot be cured. After each long rest the creature must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, they gain 1 level of exhaustion. If the creature has eaten fresh food in the past day, a successful saving throw reduces the creature's level of exhaustion by 1 level. When a successful saving throw reduces the creature's level of exhaustion below 1 they are cured. A remove disease spell does not remove the affliction, but suppresses the symptoms for 1 week.

disease.name: Devil Chills
entries: Also known as "red ache", this disease saps its victims vigor and strength until they too weak to even move. Spread by devils, tieflings are naturally immune to this disease. This disease is carried by some fiendish creatures, typically devils and other denizens of the Nine Hells. Mere contact is seldom enough to transmit the disease, and injuries are typically required for contraction.

When exposed to the disease a humanoid creature must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or becoming infected. The disease incubates for {@dice 1d4} days before symptoms begin. Initially, sufferers display a veiny red rash across the body, typically emanating from the point of injury. Infected creatures have disadvantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.

In addition, the creature's melee weapon attacks deal minimum damage. At the end of each long rest, the creature must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature gains 1 level of exhaustion. On a successful saving throw, the creature reduces their exhaustion level by 1. If the creature succeeds on a saving throw against this disease while their exhaustion level is 0 they recover from the disease.

disease.name: Ghoul Fever
entries: Carried by some ghouls, this contagion is the primary means by which ghouls increase their numbers. While not all ghouls carry ghoul fever, any ghoul can be infected. It is believed ghouls purposely contract the disease by biting their flesh, injuring themselves for the opportunity to increase the size of the pack. Living creatures bitten by an infected ghoul must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or become infected. After 1 day the creature develops a fever, and the area around the injury becomes red and tender. The creature gains 1 level of exhaustion. While the creature has 1 level of exhaustion they crave raw flesh and have difficulty eating cooked meat. An infected creature must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw to consume cooked food, vomiting the meal on a failure.

At the end of end of each long rest, an infected creature must make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature gains 1 level of exhaustion. On a successful save, the DC of the saving throw is reduced by 1d6. When the saving throw DC becomes 0, the creature recovers from the disease. If the infected creature has eaten raw meat within the last 24 hours, they have disadvantage on this saving throw. A humanoid creature that dies from ghoul fever rises as a ghoul on midnight the following night. If the creature has 6 or more Hit Dice it instead becomes a ghast upon death.

disease.name: Grave Stone
entries: Its sufferers often mistaken for statues or the victims of a medusa, this disease turns infected into stone. Victims that have been restored report that their minds remain active after petrification, and are aware of the passage of weeks and months while being unable to move or act.

Spread through physical contact, even dead and petrified victims can continue the cycle of infection. When a creature comes in contact with this disease they must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or become infected. The disease starts at the point of infection, typically the hands. The skin hardens, appearing as a marbleized patch of skin in 2d4 hours. The patch of stony skin slowly spread over time, becoming less and less flexible.

At the end of each long rest, the infected creature's base walking speed is reduced by 5 feet. When its speed reaches 0 feet, the creature is petrified. Once petrified, magic such as {@spell greater restoration|phb} is required to restore the infected creature to flesh and blood. However, removing their petrification does not eradicate the disease, which must be cured separately.

disease.name: Great Pox
entries: Also known as "reveler's bane", this disease is common among prostitutes, sailors, and amorous adventures. Despite rumours to the contrary, elves are not immune to this disease. Elves and half-elves do not display symptoms of great pox or suffer negative effects, but can readily spread the disease to other races. When a creature has sexual contact with an infected creature they must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become infected. If the infected creature is symptomatic then this saving throw has disadvantage. While there are many proposed methods of preventing infection, none of these have any actual effect.

The disease lies dormant for a variable length of time, and creatures can be asymptomatic for many weeks. Symptoms of the reveler's bane appear after {@dice 2d6} weeks but the infected creature is contagious after {@dice 2d4} days. Symptoms include a rash across the hands and groin that eventually becomes painless ulcers. After each long rest, the infected creature takes 5 {@dice 2d4} poison damage and must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a failure the poison damage increases by 2 {@dice 1d4}. On a successful saving throw the damage decreases by 2 {@dice 1d4}. When a successful saving throw reduces the damage below 1 the creature symptoms go away, but the creature remain infected and must continue to make saving throws at the end of each long rest. After three consecutive failures, symptoms return, and after three consecutive successes the creature is cured.

disease.name: Jungle Fly Fever
entries: Transmitted by insect bites, this disease only infects humanoid creatures. Jungle fly fever is typically limited to tropical areas, but there are occasional outbreaks in temperate areas during warm years. After spending 12-hours in an area with insects carrying the disease, a humanoid creature must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or become infected. Alchemical repellents, spells, and other effects that ward against insects can confer either advantage on the saving throw or outright immunity depending on the nature and potency of the effect.

Symptoms of the disease appear after {@dice 2d10} days. Symptoms include headaches, fever, and nausea; symptoms of the disease are cyclic, alternating between severe and mild. The infected creature gains 1 level of exhaustion. At the end of each long rest, the affected creature must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failure they gain @{dice 1d3} levels of exhaustion. On a success the creature's level of exhaustion is reduced by {@dice 1d3} levels. When a successful saving throw reduces the creature's level of exhaustion below 1 the disease goes into remission, but the creature remain infected and continues to make saving throws. After two consecutive failures symptoms return, and after four consecutive successes the creature is cured.

disease.name: Otyugh Saliva
entries: If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw against disease or become poisoned until the disease is cured. Every 24 hours that elapse, the target must repeat the saving throw, reducing its hit point maximum by 5 {@dice 1d10} on a failure. The disease is cured on a success. The target dies if the disease reduces its hit point maximum to 0. This reduction to the target's hit point maximum lasts until the disease is cured.

disease.name: Phobic Malady
entries: Spread through bodily fluids such as blood, this disease attacks the mind, causing irrational fear. Because of their fearless nature, halflings are immune to the negative effects of this disease, but can still become infected and transmit the disease to other creatures. Creatures exposed to the disease must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become infected. After {@dice 2d10} hours the infected creature develops a high fever as the disease spreads throughout their body. The infected creature gains 2 levels of exhaustion.

After each long rest, the infected creature can make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw, removing 1 level of exhaustion on a success. When the infected creature's level of exhaustion is reduced below 1 their fever breaks, but the secondary symptoms of the disease appear. The infected creature suffering the secondary symptoms is vulnerable to psychic damage and has disadvantage on saving throws to avoid being frightened. Additionally, the infected creature develops a strong phobia, typically towards something they already consider frightening.

When exposed to the subject of their phobia, the creature is frightened and must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a success they can act normally (but are still frightened). On a failure they must attempt to leave the area of the subject of their phobia, and if they cannot leave, they are stunned until the subject of their phobia is removed. They can repeat this saving throw at the end of their turn, ending the desire to flee or the stunned condition on a success. There is no cure for the phobic malady, and sufferers remain infected until the disease is cured by spells such as lesser restoration or heal. Spells and effects that remove fear suppress the disease and its symptoms for the duration.

disease.name: Psychic Curse
entries: This disease attacks the mind, opening mental doorways and granting the infected creature psychic abilities. The corpses of creatures slain by this virus are the primary means of infection, but naturally telepathic creatures can contract this disease through contact with the mind of an infected creature, and transmit the infection to other creatures they psychically contact. When a humanoid creature is exposed to this disease they must make a DC 13 Intelligence saving throw or become infected. Symptoms begin immediately after infection, with slight feelings of disorientation and a slight buzzing sound in the ears. These symptoms pass shortly, fading within an hour.

At the end the first long rest following infection, the infected creature gains the ability to cast detect thoughts as an action. The spellcast ability for this spell is the higher of the creature's Intelligence and Charisma ability scores. After this spell has been cast the creature must complete a short or long rest before they can cast it again. After each long rest the infected creature can cast the spell an additional time between rests. When within 60-feet of six or more creatures experiencing strong emotions - such as during combat or a stirring theatrical performance - an infected creature must make a DC 8 Wisdom saving throw or experience painful headaches that last for 1 hour.

While suffering from the headache, the creature takes a - 1 penalty to attack rolls and ability checks that rely on sight or hearing. After each long rest, the duration of the headaches increases by 1 hour. When the headaches last at least 8 hours the infected creature must succeed a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw at the end of each headache, gaining an indefinite madness on a failure. When the headaches last at least 10 hours, at the start of a headache the infected creature must succeed a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or take 22 {@damage 4d10} psychic damage. A creature reduced to 0 hit points by this psychic damage is killed, as the massive psionic pressure causes the creature's brain to explode.

Fluid from the brain and spine of a naturally telepathic creature can cure the disease. A character who has proficiency with the Medicine skill can extract this fluid, which takes an hour from a living creature or half that time from a dead creature. The brain of a medium creature provides one dose and a large creature provided four doses. Taking a dose of medication allows an infected creature to make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, curing the disease on a success.

disease.name: Scarlet Blight
entries: An infectious disease that spreads through proximity with infected creatures or their bodily fluids. Virulent and dangerous, the disease would be more rampant if not for the visible signs of illness. The infection moves slowly, and symptoms do not manifests for {@dice 3d6} days. During the incubation period infected creatures are not contagious. Symptoms include fluid filled blisters, fever, and a red rash. A creatures that starts its turn within 5 feet of a symptomatic creature, touches the bodily fluids of an injected creature, or holds an item used by an infected creature risk infection.

When a humanoid creature comes in contact with the disease, they must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become infected. After each long rest the infected creature has their hit point maximum reduced by 7 {@dice 2d6} and must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a success the DC for this saving throw is reduced by 1d6. A creature that fails three of these saving throws becomes blinded until its vision is restored by spells such as @{spell lesser restoration|phb} or {@spell heal|phb}.

When the DC of the saving throw drops to 0 the creature has recovered from the disease, and their hit point maximum increases by 3 {@dice 1d6} after each long rest until it returns to normal. If a creature naturally recovers from scarlet blight they are immune to the disease and cannot be infected again.

disease.name: Shadow's Grasp
entries: This magical illness consumes the victim's shadow before they fade and become a shadow themselves. This disease is transferred by physical contact with an infected creature, either a still living victim or a shadow formed by the disease. Living humanoid creatures that come into contact with an infected creature succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or become infected. The initial symptoms are a mild fever and tingling across the scalp. At the end of the first long rest since infection the infected creature's shadow seems blurry and indistinct.

Over the next week the infected creature's shadow fades before disappearing altogether. Seven days after infection, the creature's shadow is consumed by the disease, which moves to the infected creature's body. The infected creature becomes vulnerable to radiant damage. At the end of each long rest, one of the infected creature extremities becomes incorporeal. Incorporeal limbs function normally but with effort the creature can move their items through solid matter. Held items remain solid. The infection typically begins with the arms before moving onto the legs, with one limb becoming insubstantial each night.

After all the infected creature's limbs have become incorporeal, the disease targets their head and finally their torso. Once the infected creature's entire body has become insubstantial they begin to fade away, vanishing after 1 day. 1 minute after the creature fades away, they reanimate as a shadow. Prior to the infected creature's shadow being consumed the disease can be treated with minor magic. If a {@spell light|phb} or similar spell is cast on a diamond worth at least 30 gp and the infected creature swallows the gem they can make a new saving throw against the disease. On a successful saving throw, the creature is cured.

disease.name: Twisting Rot
entries: This disease hideously scars its victims with deformities resembling rough scales. Because of the appearance of its victims, this disease is often known as "scaly blight" and is often blamed on association with reptilian humanoids such as {@creature Kobold|MM|kobolds} or {@race dragonborn|phb}. Prolonged contact with the victims of this disease can result in infection. For each day spent in contact with an infected creature, a humanoid creature must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or catch the disease. If the creature succeeds on three consecutive saving throws to avoid infection, they are immune to twisting rot.

The disease lays dormant for some time before the infected creature begins to show signs of illness. Symptoms do not begin for {@dice 3d6} months. The disease causes sore skin as patches of pale scaly bumps appear across the body. If the disease is not cured, these lumps eventually spread cover the entire body. The disease causes numbness in the extremities, making delicate manipulation tricky and leading to repeated injuries that often become infected with other diseases. The infected creature has disadvantage on Constitution saving throws related to diseases as well as on checks requiring finesse, such as Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) or treating injuries with Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}).

In areas where the disease is prevalent, infected creatures are often shunned, and also have disadvantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks with those fearing infection. Creatures stricken with twisting rot remain infected until they die or the disease is cured with magic. There are a number of herbs and tonics that are said to cure the disease, but no known treatment has any lasting effect.

disease.name: Zombie Sickness
entries: Spread through the bite of infected undead creatures, living beings that perish while infected with this disease rise as zombies. When a living creature take damage from the natural attack of an infected undead creature the creature must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or becoming infected. Zombie sickness is typically transmitted through bites, but occasionally claws can also transmit the disease. The disease moves quickly and symptoms begin in {@dice 2d6} hours as the infected creature experiences a sudden fever. The infected creature suffers 1 level of exhaustion and cannot regain hit points by spending Hit Dice. After each hour the infected creature must succeed a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or take 7 {@damage 2d6} necrotic damage. In addition, the creature reduces their maximum hit points by the necrotic damage taken. If the creature's hit point maximum is reduced to 0 it immediately dies. All living creatures that die while infected with this disease arise as a zombie after {@dice 1d4} minutes. There is no cure for zombie sickness other than spells such as {@spell lesser restoration|phb} or {@spell heal|phb}.

entries.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, you can move up to your movement speed toward a hostile creature you can see or hear. You must end this move closer to the enemy than you started.

entries.name: Primal Intuition
entries: You have proficiency in two of the following skills of your choice: {@skill Animal Handling}, {@skill Insight}, {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Medicine}, {@skill Nature}, {@skill Perception}, and {@skill Survival}.

entries.name: Relentless Endurance
entries: When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. You can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Wild Rider
entries: You have advantage on checks made to control ridable mounts and are able to use your Strength for {@skill Animal Handling} checks. In addition, you have proficiency in {@skill Survival}.

items.name: Regional Origin (choose 1)
entries: If you are from Dreshmoor, you have Distinct Coloration. If you are from Zir, you have Desert Adaption.

entries.name: Distinct Coloration
entries: While in an environment that matches your scale color, you have advantage on Stealth (Dexterity) checks.

entries.name: Desert Adaptation.
entries: You are naturally adapted to hot climates, as described in chapter 5 of the Dungeon Master's Guide and are not hindered by difficult terrain when in sandy environments. As a result, the Reptilians of Zir have a mix of grey to brown tones on their scales.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Strength score increases by 2, and your Dexterity score increases by 1.

entries.name: Age
entries: Giff mature at roughly the same rate humans do, becoming adults in their late teens. However, giff have shorter lifespans on average, generally living no longer than 70-80 cycles.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Giff have a strict adherence to the law, thanks to their militaristic tendencies. To them, the tenets of law are held above all morals. The only good and evil, in their minds, are those who dare betray giff overall. Of course, there are always exceptions, but they are quite rare.

entries.name: Size
entries: Giff are quite tall, standing 7–8 feet on average, and incredibly stocky. The average giff can weigh as much as 850–1,000 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Headfirst Charge
entries: You can use your action to make a special attack with your hippo-like head. If you move at least 10 feet in a straight line that ends within 5 feet of a Large or smaller creature before you use this action, that creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw with a DC equal to 8 + your Strength modifier + your proficiency bonus or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Firearms Knowledge
entries: You are proficient with small arm and long arm firearms. Additionally, you ignore the loading property of these weapons.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one extra language of your choice.

spell.name: Soulforging

m.text: a complete warforged body worth 10,000 gp

entries: You and a willing humanoid subject must chant an incantation in unison during the entire casting time. At the end of this period the subject's soul and consciousness leave its body. The subject must make a DC 15 Charisma saving throw. If it fails, you take {@damage 2d10} psychic damage and {@damage 2d10} radiant damage from waves of uncontrolled energy ripping out from the disembodied spirit. You can maintain the spell, allowing the subject to repeat the saving throw at the end of each of your turns, with the same consequence to you for each failure. If you choose not to maintain the spell or are unable to do so, the subject's soul is traumatically drawn back to its body; the subject immediately drops to 0 hit points and is dying. If the save succeeds, the subject's soul is transferred into the waiting warforged body and immediately animates the constructed body. The subject is now a warforged. It loses all of its previous racial traits and gains warrfoged traits. The subject's original body dies and cannot be returned to life by any means unless its soul is freed from the warforged body. If the spellcaster dies during a soulforging, the subject also dies and its soul becomes a wraith. Up to four other spellcasters of at least 5th level can assist you in casting soulforging. Each assistant reduces the DC of the subject's Charisma saving throw by 1. In the event of a failed saving throw, the spellcaster and each assistant take damage. An assistant who drops out of the casting can't rejoin.

spell.name: Frigid Smite
entries: The next time you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack before this spell ends, the weapon is enshrouded in freezing energy, and the attack deals an extra {@damage 3d8} cold damage to the target. Additionally, the target is {@condition restrained} by ice for 1 minute. A creature {@condition restrained} by the ice can use its action to make a Strength check against your spell save DC. On a success, it frees itself.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Frozen Flash
entries: A frigid beam of blue-white light streaks toward a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, it takes {@damage 7d10} cold damage, and its speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of your next turn.
In addition, creatures made of mostly or wholly water make a Constitution saving throw at disadvantage and have their movement reduced to 0 on a failed save.

If used on a watery or water like surface, the spell freezes up to a 30-foot radius and up to 10 feet thick of ice. The ice has an AC of 12 and 30 hit points per 10 ft section. Creatures that are within the water must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell DC or become {@condition restrained} in the ice until they are removed.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: The spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d10} for each spell slot used above 5th. The creature is slowed by 20 feet if cast using a 7th level spell slot and the creature is slowed to 0 movement speed at level 9. Each spell slot above 5th increases the freezing effect of water or water like surfaces radius by 5 feet.

spell.name: Gorgon's Glare

components.m: a chip of a petrified creature and a piece of snakeskin

entries: You create a horrifying illusion, changing your face to that of a horrifying monster. Your hair appears to be composed of snakes and your face looks reptilian. Your eyes turn a deep, serpentine gold.

As part of the action to cast this spell and as an action thereafter, you can target a creature that you can see and that can see you within 30 feet. The target must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell DC. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the creature is instantly {@condition petrified}. Otherwise, a creature that fails the save begins to turn to stone and is {@condition restrained}. The {@condition restrained} creature must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn, becoming {@condition petrified} on a failure or ending the effect on a success. The petrification lasts until the creature is freed by the greater restoration spell or other similar magic.

Unless surprised, a creature can avert its eyes to gain advantage on the saving throw at the start of its turn. A target who is affected by the {@condition blinded} condition or closes their eyes at the start of their turn does not make a saving throw. A creature that closes their eyes is considered {@condition blinded}. If the creature does so, it can't see you until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If the creature looks at you in the meantime, it must immediately make the save. A creature can use its action to make an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to disbelieve the illusion, at which point the horrifying visage becomes faint and transparent, but cannot avert its eyes if it does this. Creatures with {@sense truesight} are unaffected by this spell.

If you see yourself reflected on a polished surface within 30 feet of it and in an area of bright light, you may make an Intelligence save to recognize it's your own illusion; on a failed save, you are affected by your own gaze.

spell.name: Greater Contingency

m.text: a statuette of yourself smelted from adamantine and decorated with gems worth at least 5,000 gp

entries: Choose a spell of 7th level or lower that you can cast, that has a casting time of 1 action to 1 hour, and that can target you. You cast that spell-called the contingent spell-as part of casting greater contingency, expending spell slots for both, but the contingent spell doesn't come into effect. Instead, it takes effect when a certain circumstance occurs. You describe that circumstance when you cast the two spells. For example, a greater contingency cast with {@spell plane shift|PHB} might stipulate that {@spell plane shift|PHB} comes into effect if you are forced to another plane of existence.
The contingent spell takes effect immediately after the circumstance is met for the first time, whether or not you want it to, and then greater contingency ends.

The contingent spell takes effect only on you, even if it can normally target others. You can use only one greater contingency spell at a time. If you cast this spell again, the effect of another greater contingency spell on you ends. Also, greater contingency ends on you if its material component is ever not on your person.

spell.name: Harmonious Attunement

components.m: a statuette of the creature you are casting this spell on worth 100 gold

entries: Touch an item and the creature that is going to attune to the item that requires attunement. Over the course of casting this spell, that creature is now attuned to the item immediately instead of taking 1 hour to attune to the item.

spell.name: Illumination
entries: A creature or object you touch begins to shed bright, pure light out to a radius of 60 feet, and dim light out to a radius of 120 feet. This light is daylight. Several effects occur within the bright light created by this spell:

items: Anything within the bright light faintly glows, and the sound of its movement echoes. Every creature gains a +5 bonus to its passive {@skill Perception} and advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks to notice anything touched by the light.

Any {@condition invisible} creature within this bright light appears as a shadowy figure resembling its concealed form, negating the effect of being {@condition invisible} to creatures that can see the figure.
Any creature or object that is magically altered to change its form (or apparent form) appears as a stark black version of itself while it remains within the bright light.

If any of this bright light overlaps with an illusion that forces a saving throw or changes the environment, and any area of darkness created by a spell cast at 3rd level or lower, the spell that created the darkness or illusion is dispelled.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th or 7th level, its duration increases to 1 hour. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 8th or 9th level, its duration increases to 8 hours.

spell.name: Imbue with Spell Ability
entries: You transfer one of your prepared spells, and the ability to cast them, to another creature. The spell chosen can be no greater than 3rd level.

Upon casting this spell, you cannot prepare a new 4th-level spell to replace it until the target uses the imbued spell, is reduced to 0 hit points, or until you dismiss the Imbue with Spell Ability spell's effect as a bonus action.

To cast a spell with a verbal component, the subject must be able to speak. To cast a spell with a somatic component, it must have humanoid hands. To cast a spell with a material component or focus, it must have the materials or focus.

spell.name: Infernal Rain

m.text: a 1 lb piece of brimstone encrusted with gems worth 100 gp for each creature summoned, which the spell consumes

entries: {@i Pieces of rock are tossed in the air and living fire and brimstone take their place.}

As an action, you throw the piece(s) of brimstone into the air and they catch fire and begin to grow in size. The piece(s) of brimstone that you threw into the air become Infernals and appear in an unoccupied space within 10 feet of each other within the range of the spell. The Infernals are under your control and will follow your spoken commands.

After the duration ends or upon their death, the Infernals explode causing creatures within a 20ft radius of the Infernal(s) to make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell DC taking {@damage 8d6} fire damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful save. If the fire damage caused by the Infernal's summoning as part of this spell reduces a creature to 0 hit points, it kills that creature and it becomes ash. You can summon a number Infernals equal to your spell casting ability modifier with this spell.

spell.name: Invisibility Purge
entries: You surround yourself with a sphere of power with a radius of 15ft that negates all forms of invisibility. The first time an {@condition invisible} creature is in the area or starts their turn there, the {@condition invisible} creature must make a Charisma saving throw against your spell DC. On a failed save, the spell or effect is considered dispelled and the target cannot benefit from the {@condition invisible} condition. Spells of 2nd level or lower that provide invisibility are automatically dispelled.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th or higher, increase the radius by 5ft per spell level.

spell.name: Invisibility to Undead
entries: You touch a creature and they become {@condition invisible} to undead.

Roll {@dice 5d8}; the total is how many hit points of creatures this spell can effect. Undead within 20 feet of the target are affected in ascending order of their current hit points (ignoring {@condition unconscious} creatures).
Starting with the undead that has the lowest current hit points, each creature affected by this spell treats the touched creature as being {@condition invisible} for the duration.

Subtract each undead creature's hit points from the total before moving on to the creature with the next lowest hit points. A creature's hit points must be equal to or less than the remaining total for that creature to be affected.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, roll an additional {@dice 2d8} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Iron Flesh

m.text: an ironwood statuette of yourself worth 100 gp

entries: This spell turns your flesh to an iron-like substance for protection. For the duration, you have resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing and slashing damage. In addition, this spell makes it to where your AC can't be less than 18, regardless of what armor you are wearing.

spell.name: Ironwood

components.m: wood weighing as much as the intended item and shaped into the object

entries: Ironwood is a spell used to create a magical metal-like substance from normal wood. While remaining natural wood in almost every way, ironwood is as strong and heavy as metal. Spells that affect metal do not function on ironwood. Spells that affect wood do affect ironwood, although ironwood does not burn. Using this spell with wood shape or woodworking tools, you can fashion wooden items that function as their metallic counterparts. Thus, wooden plate armor and wooden swords can be created as durable as their metallic counterparts. If the ironwood objects are under the effect of an antimagic field, they are considered normal wood objects.

spell.name: Liveoak
entries: This spell turns an oak or similar tree into a protector or guardian. The spell can be cast on only a single tree at a time; while Liveoak is in effect, you can't cast it again on another tree. The tree on which the spell is cast must be within 10 feet of your dwelling place, within a place sacred to you, or within 300 feet of something that you wish to guard or protect. If the Liveoak would travel or is moved more than 300 ft from where it was awakened, the spell ends.

Liveoak must be cast on a healthy, Huge oak or similar tree. A triggering phrase of up to 15 words is placed on the targeted tree. The Liveoak spell triggers the tree into animating as an awakened tree.
If liveoak is dispelled, the tree takes root immediately, wherever it happens to be. If released by you, the tree tries to return to its original location before taking root.

The awakened tree does what you ask of it but it must be given a purpose at the time of its animation. Such as protecting you and your companions, alerting you of creature approaching you while you rest and other similar actions
You can create a permanent Liveoak by casting this spell on the same tree every day for 30 days.

spell.name: Lockbox

m.text: a key and an adamantine box up to 10 cubic feet in size worth 1000 gp

entries: This spell turns an ordinary box into a magical lockbox. This magical lockbox cannot be opened by anyone except by the person who holds the key and speaks the command word. The lock cannot be picked with {@item Thieves' tools} or similar items. Items placed in this lockbox cannot total to be greater than 100 lbs. Items placed inside the lockbox cannot be detected by divination spells. The lockbox's magical effect cannot be detected or identified.

spell.name: Magic Vestment
entries: You touch a suit of non-magical armor or a non-magical shield. For the duration, that armor or shield becomes a magic item that provides a +1 bonus to the wearer's or wielder's AC.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th or higher, the bonus increases to +2. When you use a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the bonus increases to +3.

spell.name: Metal to Wood
entries: This spell allows you to convert non-magical metal objects into wood. This spell converts a number of metal objects into wood equal to your spellcasting ability modifier or up 500 lbs of metal.

Weapons converted from metal to wood take a -2 penalty on attack and damage rolls. The AC of metal armor converted from metal to wood is reduced by 2. Weapons changed by this spell break on any natural attack roll of 1 or 2 and armor changed by this spell loses an additional point of AC when struck by a critical hit. When the AC of armor is reduced to 10, it is destroyed. An antimagic field suppresses this effect. Ironwood ignores the penalties caused by this spell.

spell.name: Mithral Form

components.m: mithral material that has an equal weight of the target

entries: Target one object or construct made of metal that you can touch. Over the next hour, if the target and material components are within reach, the target turns into mithral. If the target is an object, its weight is halved and it has a slight blue glow. If the target is a construct, it is treated as if it is wearing {@item Mithral Chain Mail} armor and is considered proficient.

spell.name: Nightmare
entries: You send a hideous and unsettling phantasmal vision to a specific creature of your choice that is on the same plane of existence as you. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw, modified by how well you know the target, to resist the vision. On a failed save they suffer through the vision; on a successful save they do not dream that night and otherwise rest as normal. The target repeats this saving throw at the end of each long rest, ending the spell on a success.

entries.caption: Nightmare Table
rows: Secondhand (you have heard of the target)
Body part, lock of hair, bit of nail, or the like

entries: The vision prevents restful sleep. It causes {@damage 1d10} psychic damage, increases the target's {@condition exhaustion} by one level, and makes them unable to regain spell slots for the next 24 hours. Each consecutive night of visions increases the target's {@condition exhaustion} by one additional level; two nights of consecutive visions increases {@condition exhaustion} to level 2, three nights of visions increases {@condition exhaustion} to level 3, and so on.
A dispel evil and good spell cast on the target while you are casting the spell dispels the visions and causes you to be {@condition stunned} for 10 minutes.

If the target is awake when the spell begins, you can choose to end the spell or to enter a trance until the target goes to sleep, whereupon you become alert again and complete the casting. If you are disturbed during the trance, you must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the targets spell DC or 15 if the target does not have a spell DC.

If you choose to enter a trance, you are not aware of your surroundings or the activities around you while in the trance. You are defenseless, both physically and mentally, while in the trance (you always fail any saving throw, for example).
Creatures who don't sleep or dream, such as elves, are immune to this spell.

spell.name: Eldritch Being
entries: You transform yourself into a being of crackling magical energy. You become incorporeal, allowing you to move through nonmagical barriers, you have a flying speed of 30 feet, and you have immunity to piercing, slashing, and bludgeoning damage from nonmagical sources. You also have immunity to force damage.

While transformed, your {@spell eldritch blast|PHB}, {@spell eldritch burst|WorldofCollabris}, and {@spell eldritch grenade|WorldofCollabris} spells deal maximum damage. If you are hit by one of these spells cast by another creature, you take no damage and instead heal hit points equal to the spell's damage.

While you remain transformed, any creature killed by your {@spell eldritch blast|PHB}, {@spell eldritch burst|WorldofCollabris}, or {@spell eldritch grenade|WorldofCollabris} spells dies in an explosion of magical energy that deals {@damage 6d10} damage to all creatures within 10 feet.

spell.name: Eldritch Armor
entries: A crackling field of energy surrounds you, manifesting as a pale green light. Whenever a creature hits you with a melee attack while this spell is active, this energy lashes out and that creature takes {@damage 1d4} force damage.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage dealt increases by {@dice 1d4} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Eldritch Burst
entries: You create a burst of crackling energy that explodes out from you. Each creature within range, other than you, must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d8} force damage.
The spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d8} when you reach 5th level ({@dice 2d8}), 11th level ({@dice 3d8}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d8}).

spell.name: Eldritch Shield
entries: You create a translucent dome of crackling energy with a 30-foot radius, centered on you. While you maintain your concentration on this spell, you are unable to move more than 5 feet on your turn, though you may take actions as normal. If you voluntarily move more than 5 feet on your turn, the spell ends. This spell does not end if another creature or effect moves you more than 5 feet.

This dome forms a shield of solid magical energy. This shield has 100 hit points and an AC of 15. The shield has resistance to non-magical damage from piercing, bludgeoning, and slashing weapons, and is immune to psychic, poison, and force damage. If the shield is reduced to 0 hit points, the spell ends. The shield automatically fails Dexterity saving throws against spells, attacks, or other effects. The shield does not have a mind or physical body, and automatically succeeds on all other saving throws.

Physical objects cannot move through this shield unless they are worn or carried by a living creature. Any creature attempting to pass through the shield - from either side-must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 6d6} force damage and is pushed back 5 feet.
On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and successfully passes through the shield.

Any spells or magical effect of 4th-level or lower are unable to penetrate the shield and instead crash against the shield. A spellcaster who casts such a spell can't target a creature or object on the other side of the shield. Any spells already affecting a creature on either side of the shield remain in place when this spell is cast, and this spell does not affect concentration, regardless of whether a targeted creature is on the opposite side of the shield.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the shield's hit points increase by 50 for each slot level above 4th. Additionally, the shield is able to stop spells and magical effects of a level equal to or lower than the slot level used.

spell.name: Steel Mind
entries: You touch one willing creature and provide them with a measure of mental protection against fear. The target creature cannot be {@condition frightened} for the duration. If the target creature is already {@condition frightened} when you cast this spell, they are no longer {@condition frightened}.

spell.name: Lashing Tentacle
entries: You summon a single writhing tentacle from the ground near a creature of your choice within range. The target creature must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d10} bludgeoning damage, or half as much on a failed save. On a failed save, the creature is also {@condition restrained} by the tentacle for the duration.

On its turn, a creature {@condition restrained} by this tentacle may use an action to make a Strength or Dexterity check (its choice) against your spell save DC. On a success, the creature frees itself and the spell ends. On a failed check, the creature takes an additional {@damage 1d10} bludgeoning damage and remains {@condition restrained} for the duration.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the initial damage increases by {@dice 1d10} for each slot level above 1st. Subsequent damage does not increase, regardless of slot level used.

spell.name: Psyburn
entries: You link your mind to another creature that you can see within range. The target must make a Charisma saving throw.

On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 3d10} psychic damage, or half as much damage on a successful save. You also take psychic damage equal to half the total damage inflicted on the target. If you are resistant or immune to psychic damage, that resistance or immunity applies to this damage.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d10} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Woeful Wail
entries: You unleash an unearthly wail targeting creatures of your choice within range. Fiends and undead are unaffected by this spell.

The targets must make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes {@damage 4d10} psychic damage, or half as much damage on a successful one. Additionally, any creature who fails its saving throw while concentrating on a spell automatically loses concentration on their spell.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d10} foreach spell slot above 3rd.

spell.name: Forced Projection
entries: You touch one creature and force their soul out of their body. The target must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, you push the target's soul out of its body and launch the soul 120 feet in a straight line. The target's physical body instantly becomes {@condition unconscious} and falls {@condition prone}. The target's soul appears as a ghostly version of the target's physical form.

The soul is incorporeal and passes through walls and other nonmagical barriers. The soul is immune to all damage and cannot be destroyed. The target's soul has a flying speed of 40 feet and is able to take actions as the target normally would, including cast spells or other effects that the target knows, but is unable to interact with any physical objects unless the object is specifically able to interact with incorporeal beings.
If the soul touches its body, the soul returns to the body. If the body has more than 0 hit points when the soul touches it, the target regains consciousness but remains {@condition prone}.
If the target's physical body dies without its soul, the soul fades out of existence and passes on to the afterlife.

spell.name: Amphibious
entries: You target up to four willing humanoids within range, transforming them into amphibious beings. The targets' hands and feet become webbed, the targets develop gills, gain the ability to breath underwater, and gain a swim speed of 40 feet. Targets are otherwise unchanged, retaining their normal mode of respiration and keeping all of their abilities.
However, affected creatures have disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) and Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, this spell can target two additional willing humanoids for each slot level above 5th.

spell.name: Inner Demon
entries: You unleash the darkness within yourself and transform into a demonic entity. The transformation is unique to each caster and may involve your skin turning into rough scales, your body being covered in coarse red fur, or some other similarly demonic change. For the duration, you have resistance to fire damage and poison damage, and you have advantage on all Constitution saving throws.

You gain the ability to make a claw attack with your bare hand as an action, provided you have at least one free hand to make this attack. This attack deals {@damage 2d6} slashing damage and {@damage 2d6} poison damage. Targets hit by your claw attack must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} until the end of their next turn.
Additionally, while transformed, you may cast the fiendish flame cantrip as a bonus action if you know the spell.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage for your claw attack increases by {@dice 1d6} slashing and {@damage 1d6} poison damage for each slot level above 5th.

spell.name: Ill Wind
entries: You summon a chill breeze which brings misfortune in its wake.

Each creature within a 20 foot radius centered on a point within range must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or become cursed for the duration of the spell. While cursed, the creatures have disadvantage on all ability checks and saving throws related to one ability score of your choice. All creatures targeted by this spell suffer disadvantage on saving throws and ability checks for the same ability score.
A {@spell remove curse|phb} spell ends this effect.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: If you cast this spell using a 7th level spell slot, the duration increases to 10 minutes. If you cast this spell using an 8th level spell slot, the duration increases to 1 hour. If you cast this spell using a 9th level spell slot, the duration increases to 24 hours and doesn't require concentration.

spell.name: Psychic Stronghold
entries: You create a mental barrier that protects every creature within range (including any creatures hostile to you). The barrier takes the form of a swirling mist that expands out from you in a 60 foot radius, though you may choose to voluntarily limit the range. Any creature within the spell's range (or who enteres the affected area while it remains in effect) is immediately aware of the spell's benefits. Once cast, the spell remains centered on the location where it was cast and does not move with you.

While the spell is in effect, all creatures in range have resistance to psychic damage. If a creature in the affected area already has resistance to psychic damage through some other means, they instead gain immunity to psychic damage. Creatures in the affected area also have advantage on all Wisdom and Intelligence saving throws while they remain in the affected area.
Any illusions in range when this spell is cast are immediately dispelled, and all illusion spells cast in the affected area automatically fail while the spells remains in effect.
Additionally, any attempt by an outside entity to use scrying or a similar divination spell or effect targeting any creature or location in the affected area automatically fails.

The benefits of this spell only apply to creatures within the affected area. Any creature who leaves the affected area loses the spell's benefits, and any creature who enters the area gains these benefits.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the spell's duration increases by 1 hour for each slot level above 6th.

spell.name: Annihilation Wave
entries: You create a blast of negative energy that expands out from you in a line, 60 feet long and 10 feet wide. All creatures in range must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 12d6} necrotic damage, or half as much on a successful save.
Any plant creatures or magical plants in range make their saving throw with disadvantage and take maximum damage from this spell.
All nonmagical plants that aren't creatures, such as tree or shrubs, do not make a saving throw; they simply wither and die.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 8th level or higher, the spell's damage increases by {@dice 4d6} for each slot level above 7th.

spell.name: Bedlam
entries: You enchantment creatures of your choice within range, causing them to suffer the effects of madness. A targeted creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, they must roll for an effect on the Short-Term Madness table (Dungeon Master's Guide, p. 259). The creature suffers from that effect of short-term madness for the duration of this spell.
A creature affected by this spell may repeat its saving throw at the end of each of its turns to try to end this effect, though the creature makes these subsequent saving throws with disadvantage.

If you maintain your concentration for the full duration of this spell, any creature affected by this spell for the full minute continues to suffer the effect of Short-Term Madness for an additional {@dice 1d10} minutes after the spell ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a 8th level spell slot, the range increases to a 60-foot radius. When you cast this spell using a 9th level spell slot, the range increases to a 100-foot radius.

spell.name: Patron Blast
entries: You fire a beam of conentrated energy at one creature within range. The target must make a saving throw against this spell. On a failed save the target takes {@damage 8d10} damage, or half as much damage on a successful one. The type of saving throw and the damage type vary based on the nature of your warlock patron, as described in the table below. If you have a warlock patron other than those listed here, the DM will determine the saving throw and damage type for this spell.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 2d10} for each slot level above 5th.

spell.name: Conditional Curse
entries: You touch one creature and place a curse on them. When you cast the spell, you must loudly declare one specific action that you now forbid and a conditional requirement to end the curse. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save the target is physically unable to perform the specific action stated until the conditional requirement is met.

The forbidden action must be specific and cannot be general. You may create a curse that prevents a creature from using a specific weapon ("You may not wield Excalibur until you have proven your worth"), but you cannot create a curse that prevents a creature from using any weapon. An overly general curse fails, and the spell has no effect.

As an example - you might curse a creature by saying, "You may not return home until the sun crashes into the sea." In this example, the target creature may not return to their home until the condition is met. However, conditions may be interpreted metaphorically - in this case the target might watch the sunset over the ocean, and the curse would be broken. The DM will decide whether a specific action meets the conditional requirement of this spell.

You cannot use this spell to create curses that directly harm the target or lead directly to their death. For example, you cannot create a curse that prevents a creature from breathing. Such a curse fails, and the spell has no effect.

A {@spell remove curse|PHB} spell may end this effect, though the caster must make an ability check with their spellcasting ability against your spell save DC as of the time the conditional curse was cast. On a successful check, the curse is removed and the spell ends. On a failure, the curse continues for the duration.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: If you cast this spell as a 7th level spell, the duration is 10 days. If you cast this spell as an 8th level spell, the duration is 1 year. If you cast this spell as a 9th level spell, the spell continues until it is dispelled or the condition is met.

spell.name: Beguiling Mist
entries: You summon a faint, pink mist that covers the ground within a 30 foot radius centered on you. This mist remains centered on your for the duration and moves as you move.
All creatures within range (except for you) must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a creature has disadvantage on all subsequent Wisdom saving throws for the duration.
Any creature who enters the mist while the spell remains in effect must also succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on all subsequent Wisdom saving throws for the duration.

A creature must only make one saving throw against this spell. Once they have made a saving throw, they do not need to make another against the same casting of this spell, even if they leave the affected area and reenter it while the spell remains in effect.
Creatures that can't be {@condition charmed} are immune to the effects of this spell.

spell.name: Shape of the Hellspawned Stalker
entries: Red fur sprouts from your skin, and your spine twists. You hunch over until you stand on four clawed feet. A great heat fires your belly, and tendrils of black smoke curl from your fanged mouth, as you take the form of a {@creature hell hound|MM}.

The transformation lasts for the duration, or until you drop to 0 hit points, fall {@condition unconscious}, or die. You assume the hit points of your new form. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before you transformed. If you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. As long as the excess damage doesn't reduce your normal form to 0 hit points, you aren't knocked {@condition unconscious}. You are limited in the actions you can perform by the nature of your new form, and you cannot speak, cast spells, or take any other action that requires hands or speech. Your gear melds into the new form. You cannot activate, use, wield, or otherwise benefit from any of your equipment

spell.name: Abyssal Gaze
entries: You gaze at one creature you can see within range and cause it to experience a disorienting mental vision of absolute nothingness. When casting this spell, your eyes become inky black voids, as do the eyes of the target (if the target has eyes). The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. The target takes {@damage 6d6} psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

If a humanoid target fails their saving throw, they must also roll for an effect on the {@table Short-Term Madness|DMG} table. The creature suffers from that effect of short-term madness for the duration of this spell. A humanoid affected in this way may repeat its saving throw at the end of each of its turns to try to end this effect.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 2d6} for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Invoke Patron

m.text: a small offering for your patron with a minimum 25 gp value, which is consumed by this spell

entries: You contact your patron and ask up to three questions which can be answered with a single word or a short phrase of no more than three or four words. You must ask your questions before the spell ends. The answers that you receive are not necessarily correct, but reflect the answers most advantageous to your patron (and not necessarily to you)

Many patrons prefer to give cryptic hints over direct answers. Patrons are not necessarily omniscient, so you might receive "unclear" as an answer if a question pertains to information beyond your patron's knowledge. However, it is just as likely that your patron will provide false or misleading information that will cause you to take an action that is advantageous to their interests. Consider your relationship with your patron and the nature of your patron when weighing these answers.

If you cast this spell two or more times before finishing a long rest, there is a cumulative 25 percent chance for each casting after the first that you get no answer. The DM makes this roll in secret. Additionally, invoking you patron too often may annoy some patrons, and there can be other consequences (at the DM's discretion) for frequent casting of this spell.

spell.name: Shadow Self
entries: You separate your spirit from your body and imbue your soul into your own shadow. This spell renders your physical body unconcious for the duration. If your body is not supported in some way (such as lying on a bed or sitting in chair), your body slumps to the ground and takes {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning damage.

While you are a shadow, you retain your hit points, AC, senses, skills, and abilities. Your shadow self is incorporeal and has a flying speed of 30 feet. You are unable to use any of your equipment unless your equipment is specifically able to interact with incorporeal creatures. You may not cast any spells while you are a shadow. If you attempt to cast a spell, then that spell fails and your soul is instantly sent back into your physical body. If your shadow self moves away from your physical body, you body does not cast a shadow for the duration of the spell.

Your shadow self is amorphous and can fit through spaces as narrow as 1 inch wide. While in darkness, your shadow self can take the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action and has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.
You may voluntarily end this spell at any time during the duration as a bonus action. When you do, your soul is instantly returned to your physical body, and you are no longer unconcious.

If your shadow self is reduced to 0 hit points, your soul is instantly sent back into your physical body. You must make a Charisma saving throw against your own spell save DC. On a success, you regain conciousness with 1 hit point. On a failure, you remain unconcious with 0 hit points.
If your physical body is reduced to 0 hit points, this spell ends and your soul is instantly sent back into your physical body.

If your soul is sent back to your body by any method other than when you volunarily end the spell, you must make a Charisma saving throw against your own spell save DC. On a failure, you are {@condition stunned} until the end of your next turn.

spell.name: Steelskin
entries: You touch one willing creature and transform them into solid steel. This spell transforms the target along with any nonmagical equipment that the target is wearing or carrying. For the duration, the target becomes {@condition petrified}. This functions as the {@condition petrified} condition (see Player's Handbook, p. 291), except that the target becomes immune to all damage except fire damage and has resistance to fire damage. The target cannot fall {@condition unconscious} while transformed in this way, but if the target has 0 hit points when the spell ends, they immediately fall {@condition unconscious} when the spell ends. The target does not need to make death saving throws while {@condition petrified} by this spell even if they suffer damage while at 0 hit points.

spell.name: Mind Shield

time.condition: when you or a target in range are hit with a spell or effect that deals psychic damage or that inflicts the charmed, frightened, or stunned condition

entries: You create a mental shield that protects one target within range that you can see. The target has resistance to psychic damage and ends any of the following conditions: {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, or {@condition stunned} and then the spell ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Stunning Reversal

time.condition: which you take when you or a target within range are hit with an attack that causes the stunned condition

entries: You prevent yourself or another target within range from becoming {@condition stunned} by a spell or other effect. This spell only prevents the stunning effect of a spell or attack. Any damage or other effects caused by the spell or attack resolve as normal.

The attacker who initiated the stunning spell or attack must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save that creature is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. If the target takes damage, it is no longer {@condition stunned}.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you may redirect the stunning effect at one additional creature within range (in addition to the attacker) for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Twist the Knife

time.condition: which you take after you hit a target with a melee attack

entries: Immediately after you hit a target with a melee attack (but before you roll damage), you may use your reaction to cast this spell. The target must make a Constitution saving throw.

On a failed save, this spell deals necrotic damage equal to the weapon damage of the melee attack that just hit, or half as much on a successful save. If you have already rolled weapon damage for this attack, you may not cast this spell.
If your melee attack is a critical hit, this spell only deals necrotic damage equal to half the total weapon damage of the attack (not the doubled damage from the critical hit).

spell.name: Vampiric Tether
